posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I wish I could have made the subject title a spoiler, but it appears I can't.

I've just finished a Baldur's and Baldur's 2 run-through and before embarking on another Dragon Age run, I'm at something of a loose end (there, that's my excuses out of the way). Thus, I find myself thinking about forbidden subjects - namely magic and its uses.

Now, a couple of things to get out of the way...I've never made an arcanist before, so will need even more babysitting than usual - yes, it's another round of dumb-ass questions from Stag on its way! Second, I've decided on Sorcerer for my first foray. Being a meleer by nature, all that preparation of spells that Wizard entails leaves me cold - give me spontaneous casting any day. Third (yes, I know...), if I'm going to do it, I don't want to confuse myself by being a spellsword or melee-mage: I want to stand behind and hurl horridness at things from afar.

My first thought was to harness the CHA synergy between Sorcerer and Bard, but then two things happened. I realized that the Sorcerer spells were always going to supercede the Bard ones, so in effect Bard would only be there for song, Tumble, and Lore, and given that I'm looking at about 26 levels of Sorcerer that wouldn't amount to very much. The second thing that happened was that I looked up the prospective classes in the Guild Filter and the Legacy Archive and there were none, which was a pretty big clue.

Then I thought about other classes with potential synergy Pally, BG and CoT. I ruled BG out purely on the basis of not wanting 2 classes I've never played before at the same time, let alone having to be evil. Pally then went in the bin having seen Valerfor's Battle Sorceress, because it's both a combat pc and far too good a build for me to get close to. So, CoT, for a bit of occasional smiting (oh, and bonus feats and saves, too).

So I was left wondering about a 3rd class. Rogue has its appeal, as it always does, but guess what popped into my mind... Yep, Monk. A little speed, Tumble, and gear.

It's probably about time I asked a question now (if anyone's still awake). Is the idea of a Sorcerer/ Monk/ CoT build a stupid one? I'm currently toying with a Sorc 26/ Monk 4/ CoT 10 split, but I don't want to hurtle down a dead-end immediately.

Cheers

Oh, and I'd appreciate it if you didn't tell anyone about this, thanks.

EDIT: Sorry, should have said that I'm looking at human. Would have been dwarf but for the CHA pen or gnome but for the xp pen. And human gets an extra feat and skill points, obvs

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Shh! I'll whisper!!!
You are thinking of a NWN sorcerer right?
And no half-breed, but a pure *whispers* m a g e.
Just to clear things out...that is.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
*Sighs* Yes. To both.

I started thinking about a full 40 level Sorcerer, but thought that might be a bit of a stretch for me. It may (or may not) be easier to construct, but another class or two would make me feel more comfortable in my own skin.

Gods, Grom's never going to speak to me again...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
(((First of all: This is brave!)))  Shh...

Maybe if we can talk about what makes a mage tick, things will become less scary.

First ((quiet)) lesson for building a sorcerer:
1) Forget all you know about BAB and AB - it is irrellevant. If you hold a weapon, it is because it has item properties you want.
2) Spell DC and Spell penertation are your new AB. You can either start reading up on it, or you can just take my word for it and get a high Cha (if sorcerer) for the Spell DC and a high casterlevel for the Spell penetration. There are feats to enhance both further, but that is secondary.
3) A high caster ability (Cha for sorcerer) also grants you extra spell slots
4) Keeping a high caster level while leveling pre epic is essential for getting powerful spells as soon as possible.

Second (secret) lesson for building a sorcerer:
You want a high spell DC to prevent your target from saving versus your spells. You want to focus on one or two spell schools to improve the DC of those spells. You have three feats you can take: Spell focus, Greater SF and Epic SF in any given spell school. You need the first to take the second, and the second to take the third. Each adds +2 to the DC of spells from that school.
You want a high enough Spell penetration to ovecome the Spell resistance of your target. You may need to boost this with extra feats if you multiclass and lower your caster level, if you take your mage to an area with foes above your level or if you just happen to play a module where the designer has added a high SR to bosses or just given SR to more monsters than usual. So this may be circumstantial.

Third (silent) lesson for building a sorcerer:
There is something called meta magic. It has two uses: 1) It changes the spell 2) it makes it possible to cast the same spell from spell slots of different spell levels. The first is important for all mages. The last is especially important for spontaneous casters, like the Sorcerer. My hottest for a sorcerer are: extend, empower, maximize and silent.

Forth....shhhh

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Mick. Given that none of the great and good have produced a Sorcerers' Guide in the Game Guides section (irresponsible people that you are), I've just had to go by what I can pick up from other builds and the wiki. Which only further confuses me as often as not.

And I do remember about meta magic - I had a thread back in 2017 entitled "Explaining Meta Magic to a Monkey" - a little sly learning.

While researching a bit about these infernal arts, when I half-contemplated Wiz, I particularly liked the look of Evocation and Conjuration schools - kewl AoE effects apart from anything else - and if I'm going to stand on a hilltop in a dress with my hands aloft I want it to look pretty damned impressive. I'll confess, not specializing as a Wiz was another attraction to going for Sorcerer.

Now, as for the other (secret, on tiptoes) info... Effectively, the deal is to swap combat feats for arcane ones. Thus, Blind Fight, Knockdown, Imp Crit can all hit the high road (I might still want to keep one or two, just in case) - particularly as a non-melee build. Then crank up both potency and volume. Hence the meta malarkey and things like Still, Extend, Empower and Max.

Now, my biggest problem (and this is only a guess, there may be way bigger ones) is likely to be preventing myself from being too squishy, which is why I was wondering about Monk and CoT as potential complementary classes.

And so the story that no one will ever know moves on...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Forth lesson for building as sorcerer (don't tell anybody):
Defense:
You already know how AC works. It works in the same way for casters.

It is even possible (shh), but somehow complicated to use shield and armor. You will then need the armor and shield feats. The best way to get them is to take a level of a class that gets them at lvl 1 like fighter, paladin, blackguard and cleric. Armor and shield interfere with arcane spells and can cause you to fail at casting your spells. You can still your spells (Still spell metamagic feat) and cast them at one spell level higher than normal, and you can take the epic Auto still feats and cast normally, despite your armor and shield. So using armor comes at a price. You have to spend feats and most probably you want to multiclass. Most sorcerers work well without, but on WoG they started playing a build known as the Exalted sorceress.

You already know how saves work. You have Spellcraft to improve the saves vs spells. You also have a fat Charisma that will give a great boost to saves if combined with the Divine grace feat of the Paladin or the Dark blessing feat of the Blackguard. This is one more of the ideas behind the Exalted sorceress. You don't have to use this, but you must know of it.

If you have good saves, Evasion can protect you from much elemental damage. You can get it early from several classes, already at lvl 1 from Monk. One more idea behind the Exalted sorceress.
Another point when using those classes is the access to Tumble as class skill.

You have access to a lot of spells that come into play for defensive purposes. They can give you different forms of AC, Damage resistence, Damage reduction, absorption of elemental damage, Self concealment, Invisibility, spell absorption etc etc.
But how to use spells falls under the lessons for playing a sorcerer.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ha - I'm getting a Game Guide by default!

With my particular thoughts for my first crack at Sorcerer, I don't want shield and armour, so let's not worry unduly about them and their impact - it was part of my thinking about taking Monk as a complementary class.

This all seems to be suggesting that Sorcerer/ Monk/ CoT might actually be a viable option (assuming I take a WF in a weapon, of course). Maybe Sor 16/ M 2/ CoT 2 pre-epic? That's a wild stab in the dark, btw.

I'll see what I can dig up about Exalted Sorceress builds as well - but Pally is a bit too LG for my liking, and BG is a build I'm not ready for yet.

Cheers

EDIT: So, presumably, I wouldn't need Still Spell if I'm not wearing armour?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: - and if I'm going to stand on a hilltop in a dress with my hands aloft I want it to look pretty damned impressive. I'll confess
Here is something to look forward to. Quite the opposite of a hilltop, but even so:

It is from Aielund second act, the Isle of the dead dungeon. And it is from the solo run with my Evil Speed Caster, but obviously before she multiclasses.
SpoilerThere are some rooms where you spawn a Warlord Mummy when you pick a magical weapon from a sarcophagus. There was a loop that let me pick the weapon and replace it and pick it and so on and spawn the room full of Warlord Mummies. I finished them all with a couple of castings of Sunburst and maybe a Firebrand to finish off any stragglers. I would not dare to try that stunt with a fighter type.
If nothing else, it was a fine picture of the mummies.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: Ha - I'm getting a Game Guide by default!

With my particular thoughts for my first crack at Sorcerer, I don't want shield and armour, so let's not worry unduly about them and their impact - it was part of my thinking about taking Monk as a complementary class.

This all seems to be suggesting that Sorcerer/ Monk/ CoT might actually be a viable option (assuming I take a WF in a weapon, of course). Maybe Sor 16/ M 2/ CoT 2 pre-epic? That's a wild stab in the dark, btw.

I'll see what I can dig up about Exalted Sorceress builds as well - but Pally is a bit too LG for my liking, and BG is a build I'm not ready for yet.

Cheers

EDIT: So, presumably, I wouldn't need Still Spell if I'm not wearing armour?
For your first build, and I mean just to learn how to build: Try first to build a pure sorcerer, just to get a feel with how to distribute abilities, when you get the different spells, what feats to take and where to put them. And what skills you have available. Keep it simple. Then you have something to work on and compare other builds with.

For playing a sorcerer, it is a step by step learning by doing process. And every level has its possibilities and challenges. You will be selecting and deselecting and using different spells as you level up. But all that comes later.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: I'll give all this a proper think...but in the meantime, I do believe these are Mick's first screenshots, so hoorah!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I've been doing some research, and have some questions, you'll be surprised to know...

Pre-epic feats. Let's assume 18-20 levels of human Sorcerer. That's 8 feats. If I ignore all combat and defensive feats (at least for now), there appear to be 10 caster feats that could be worthwhile - 9 if I go without armour/shield and so don't need Still Spell. These are Extend Spell, Empower Spell, Maximize Spell, Silent Spell, Spell Focus, Greater Spell Focus, Quicken Spell, Spell Penetration and Greater Spell Penetration. I can see the merits in all of them, but my natural instincts would be to leave Silent Spell behind if I stay back with a meat-shield or two in front. Does that make sense?

Starting Stats. My current thinking is, obviously, to max Charisma and dump Wisdom. As a secondary boost, I'm thinking Dexterity to help with AC when not in armour, but I can also see merit in both Constitution and Intelligence. Given that I'm going completely against type, I'm even thinking about dropping Strength to 10 (though I think I'd be physically sick if I dropped it any more). So how does a spread of Str 10, Dex 14, Con 10, Wis 8, Int 12 and Cha 18 sound?

Class Split. I honestly do understand Mick's reasoning in going for a full level 40 Sorcerer, but it does make me a little twitchy, despite having looked at the Yardstick Builds thread (where I think Hip was the builder, buried somewhere on page 7 or 8). Even the Exalted Sorceress has 3 classes. So I'm still keen to add a few levels of other classes myself, and the addition of Monk does seem reasonable (including in Mick's own Evil Speed Caster, above). CoT might seem an odd choice, and I'm thinking of it in epic levels only (and I appreciate I'd have to take a WF in a melee weapon first, thus losing another of the aforementioned mage feats), but it has a weird panoply of epic bonus feats, including Epic Spell Focus, Combat Casting, and so on, which could allow for more Sorcerer bonus feats in Great Charisma. It also brings Divine Wrath and great boosts to saves. In other words, I'm still thinking Sorcerer 26/ Monk 4/ CoT 10. Just tell me if it's stupid.

Spells. I entirely understand the number of base spells I can cast per day, but as far as "known spells" is concerned, once I "know" a spell, am I able to forget it and know another another one of the same level instead? For example, if I know Endure Elements at level 1, then having picked up Resist Elements at level 2 decide I'd rather know Grease at level 1, is that okay?

Oh, and as an addendum to Spells, where the bloody hell has Chromatic Orb gone? It was one of my fave level 1 Baldur's spells, and it's disappeared completely. B*s*a*ds!

It does strike me that this will likely be something of a glass cannon at early levels, and will need tlc from companions and/or summons and familiar, about which more another time...

That's where I am at the moment, anyway.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Any time you take another level of Sorcerer, you can remove spells at that time to learn others in their place.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Thanks Empyre, that's one conundrum solved (hey, if you're going to use "felicitations"...)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: I've been doing some research, and have some questions, you'll be surprised to know...
Not surprised at all, this is new stuff.
Pre-epic feats. Let's assume 18-20 levels of human Sorcerer. That's 8 feats. If I ignore all combat and defensive feats (at least for now), there appear to be 10 caster feats that could be worthwhile - 9 if I go without armour/shield and so don't need Still Spell. These are Extend Spell, Empower Spell, Maximize Spell, Silent Spell, Spell Focus, Greater Spell Focus, Quicken Spell, Spell Penetration and Greater Spell Penetration. I can see the merits in all of them, but my natural instincts would be to leave Silent Spell behind if I stay back with a meat-shield or two in front. Does that make sense?
The penetration feats are not always useful. They serve you best if you have low caster levels or if you from some other reason struggle a lot with SR.
Quicken spell let you cast immediately and adds a second casting per round. But you get the same all the time without the feat whenever you are hasted. Quicken let you cast from slots 4 levels above the original spell, so it is only useful with level 5 spells and lower. It may be useful if you decide that you need to cast a spell like Firebrand a zillion times, but most often you can live well without it.
Extend, Silent and Still all cast from slots 1 level above the original spell. Extend is useful bercause it gives longer duration to "rounds per level" spells. Still and Silent work with more spells than Extend, and are useful for that reason. If casting in armor is not a problem, you pick Silent.
Some people take the Combat casting and Improved CC feats. A high Concentration skill will be enough in most cases to avoid attacks of opportunity in defensive casting mode and spell failure from taking heavy blows.
In vanilla NWN you can cast in Expertise mode and get +5 and even +10 AC for free since you don't suffer from the AB penalty. Many module designers and PW owners have disabled that  possibility, but sometimes taking both Expertise feats are worth it.
As for the spell focus feats, grab both SF and GSF (and also ESF) in one school, and take two schools if you can afford it.
Starting Stats. My current thinking is, obviously, to max Charisma and dump Wisdom. As a secondary boost, I'm thinking Dexterity to help with AC when not in armour, but I can also see merit in both Constitution and Intelligence. Given that I'm going completely against type, I'm even thinking about dropping Strength to 10 (though I think I'd be physically sick if I dropped it any more). So how does a spread of Str 10, Dex 14, Con 10, Wis 8, Int 12 and Cha 18 sound?
You are right about Charisma, start high and take it as high as you can get it.
You are also right about Wisdom.
Intelligence 10 gives 3 full skills for a human full sorcerer. Concentration and  Spellcraft are a must. If you want more skills depends on what kind of build you make. You need 13 Int if you want Expertise. 14 int gives a modifies Spellcraft of 45 whith full ranks. 12 Int gives Spellcraft 50 with capped Intelligence, and so on.
People differ a bit when choosing between Strength, Dexterity and Constitution. You can boost them all with empowered spells if you want. I prefer Constitution for the hitpoints since this is a d4 build. Strength is good for carrying and for melee mages. Dexterity helps a bit in early levels when you hide behind your mighty badger and familiar, anxiously squeezing an x-bow between your swaety hands.
Class Split. I honestly do understand Mick's reasoning in going for a full level 40 Sorcerer, but it does make me a little twitchy, despite having looked at the Yardstick Builds thread (where I think Hip was the builder, buried somewhere on page 7 or 8). Even the Exalted Sorceress has 3 classes. So I'm still keen to add a few levels of other classes myself, and the addition of Monk does seem reasonable (including in Mick's own Evil Speed Caster, above). CoT might seem an odd choice, and I'm thinking of it in epic levels only (and I appreciate I'd have to take a WF in a melee weapon first, thus losing another of the aforementioned mage feats), but it has a weird panoply of epic bonus feats, including Epic Spell Focus, Combat Casting, and so on, which could allow for more Sorcerer bonus feats in Great Charisma. It also brings Divine Wrath and great boosts to saves. In other words, I'm still thinking Sorcerer 26/ Monk 4/ CoT 10. Just tell me if it's stupid.
Stop twitching! I proposed a pure build for educational purposes. When you have pieced together a pure sorcerer, you can start looking at what other classes may add, and you have something to compare with.
Sorcerer 26/ Monk 4/ CoT 10 is the level spread of a spellsword. It is not stupid, it is just something else.
Spells. I entirely understand the number of base spells I can cast per day, but as far as "known spells" is concerned, once I "know" a spell, am I able to forget it and know another another one of the same level instead? For example, if I know Endure Elements at level 1, then having picked up Resist Elements at level 2 decide I'd rather know Grease at level 1, is that okay?
Every time you level up you can choose to deselect known spells if you don't want them anymore, and you can choose the new ones you want. There is a limit to how many spells you can know at any given level.
Oh, and as an addendum to Spells, where the bloody hell has Chromatic Orb gone? It was one of my fave level 1 Baldur's spells, and it's disappeared completely. B*s*a*ds!
It is gone

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Excellent post Mick, thank you! I was particularly fond of the mighty badger and the sweaty hands (goodness gracious!).

Plenty more to ponder. I still can't help myself, it seems, when left to my own devices I start running straight into the sharpened arms of a meleer (sorry, "spellsword" to be fancy about it). Okay, any future twitchiness will, for now, be the result of either too much or too little whisky.

And I need to read up on more of the spells themselves. Actually, there's something to be said about this, I feel. You clever wombats who've been coming up with casters for years hardly ever give your recommendations for spells - shame on you! It's like a Fighter build just saying, "Take lots of combat feats." I appreciate that's not an entirely accurate analogy, but I trust you get my point.

Cheers (He signs off with harrumphing indignation )

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: Of course playing a sorcerer is almost all about spells. We will get to that in time. And we will start with low level spells for low level characters, so you have something to start out with.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Sorcerer 40, no twitching around!
Charisma 18 => 38 no less.

Resist your natural urge to "add" something to the character, you'll see why when you play her.
And good luck!

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content: Just chiming in to say that this is a fantastic discussion.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Alright then, I've put the twitching in a dark corner with a towel over its head while I submit a first draft (though I can still hear it whimpering).

I'll confess, when I first sat down with my trusty pencil and paper I thought, "Well, this is all pretty straightforward. I don't have many feats to play with, so it's just about getting the right one in the right place. Easy." Which is probably what casters think about constructing a melee build for the first time. But as I went on I realized that it's actually a lot more nuanced than that (typical underhanded arcanist trick). Hopefully, I've paid attention to advice thus far, so it might not be too shambolic. In any case, it's a starting point...

Soren the Slapdash Sorcerer (the name may change as progress is made)
Sorcerer 40. Human. Any alignment
1-40 PvM (sadly untested, pending a reinstallation of NwN)

STATS

Str 10
Dex 8
Con 14
Wis 8
Int 14
Cha 18 (38)

HPs - 240
Skill points - 215. Concentration 43 (45), Heal 43 (42), Lore 43 (45), Spellcraft 43 (45), Tumble (cc) 20 (20) [3 spare for some crafting malarkey or other. Probably switch out Heal and/or Lore for more crafting stuff for our BSK friends]
Saves - Fort 18, Will 21, Reflex 15. All +8 vs spells [don't like any of these, tbh, but hopefully I'll be able to buff]
AC (robes only) - [gulp] 13
BAB - 20
AB (max) - 20 (melee), 19 (ranged)
Spells - Sorcerer 9

LEVELLING [all Sorcerer, so I'm not typing them all in]

1 Extend Spell/ Expertise/ (Summon familiar [open to suggestions])
2
3 Silent Spell
4 CHA+1 (19)
5
6 Empower Spell
7
8 CHA+1 (20)
9 Maximize Spell
10
11
12 CHA+1 (21)/ Spell Focus [open to advice: quite like Evocation or Conjuration]
13
14
15 Quicken Spell
16 CHA+1 (22)
17
18 Greater Spell Focus
19
20 CHA+1 (23)
21 Great Cha I (24)
22
23 Great Cha II (25)
24 CHA+1 (26)/ Epic Spell Focus
25
26 Great Cha III (27)
27 Great Cha IV (28)
28 CHA+1 (29)
29 Great Cha IV (30)
30 Epic Spell [one of Epic Mage Armour, Epic Warding, Greater Ruin, Hellball]
31
32 CHA+1 (31)/ Great Cha VI (32)
33 Epic Spell [as above]
34
35 Great Cha VII (33)
36 CHA+1 (34)/ Great Cha VIII (35)
37
38 Great Cha IX (36)
39 Great Cha X (37)
40 CHA+1 (38)

I did wonder whether Improved Expertise might be worth it for the AC pump, but wasn't sure what to sacrifice.

And another thing...Who in the Abyss was in charge of allocating spells to schools? Haste and Mass Haste - different schools. Flame Arrow and Fireball - different schools. And so on. Were they just blindfolded and threw darts at a board?

Anyway, comments welcome (giggles less so, but still okay)

Cheers

EDIT: Should have remembered to include the spell DC. If I've got my sums right it's 30 (10+14 ability modifier+6 Epic Spell Focus) + the spell level

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
It is time to congratulate you - you have built your first sorcerer!
As far as I can judge it is a legal build (as long as you pick epic spells you qualify for).

You do most things right, and it is a build I could play without problems.
The charisma is so high that even spells from spell schools you don't focus in pose serious threats to your targets. Your high caster level also secures a very good SR penetration.

If you don't twitch, you can squeeze in another greater spell focus by removing Expertise and Quicken. You will soon learn other ways than AC to avoid damage. You may even take the epic focus in the second school, if you only take one epic spell. As for schools I often pick Evocation or Necromancy or both.

Another question is when to take the feats, and in what order. The simplest answer to that is - when you need them.
I would take SF early and GSF somewhere in mid-pre-epic. The level where you take meta-magic feats looks good
Note that epic spells need a given rank in spellcraft. If you want them, take them as early as possible (unless it messes with something you have given priority).

As for what spells belong to what schools, the logic is beyond me as well. Look up the NWNWIKI and find a table that sorts spells by school, just so you know what you're dealing with.

Formula for spell DC:
DC = 10 + spell level + ability modifier + feat modifier
The level 40 Soren has a feat modifier of 6 for his chosen school and the abilify modifier is 14 unbuffed and 20 when capped. Add 1 for level 1 spells and upwards to 9 for level 9 spells. A level 1 spell from an unfocused school has a DC of 25 if there are no charisma buffs. A level 9 spell from the focused school has DC of 45 when you cap charisma.

Lvl 40 Soren will always penetrate SR 41, and can penetrate SR 42 to 60 depending on a d20 roll.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
That's an absolutely playable pure sorcerer you have there. You basically wrote down one of the yardsticks. The other viable one sacrifices some meta for a second school focus.
You are correct about the DC (it's the highest possible), aka DC45 wail with capped Cha.
Look at you saves. Now imagine you Cha modifier added :) But first, I think Nick and Val are right, do it pure. You'll have other ways of not being affected by spells.
Consider Necro for one of your SF. Wail of the banshee is a top spell (4x better than weird) but it has a saving throw.
Depending on where you play, scribe scroll or craft wand can be taken instead of expertise (I love wands, but that's a personal preference and a WoGism.)
The last theoretical bit that remains: spell choice and how it changes during leveling.
And finally, the big one: how to play. I'm not just thinking about the theory. A lot of it, more than with any other class, is execution. By the way, I'd love to see this discussion include how people actually cast with a spontaneous meta caster. That's the holy Grail of nwn IMO (if you don't pause, like on a server.)

EDIT: and the ninja comes in the niiiiiiiiight

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks both!

A few things to say, if that's okay (and in no particular order)...

When it came to feats, I settled on Valerfor's instruction of 18 (38) Charisma (for an easy life, as much as anything), which meant I needed 10 Great Charismas. That gave me 2 spare epic feats (because I was always going to take Epic Spell Focus) and Hellball or Greater Ruin sounded kewl, while Epic Warding or Epic Mage Armour sounded sensible (it's all about balance). However, if I'm going truly untwitchy, I'm fine with Mick's suggestion about dropping Expertise and Quicken (as Haste will have a similar effect in any case) pre-epic and picking up another focus and its greater cousin, then dropping an Epic Spell for the epic focus. That way I could have both Evocation (fun) and Necromancy (serious - see, balance again). It's not that I've changed my mind about liking Conjuration (I've always liked Melf's Acid Arrow, Flame Arrow and Cloudkill), but Horrid Wilting and Wail of the Banshee (as well as all that negative energy stuff) are hard to ignore.

If I go down that route, then I'm fine to drop INT to 12 - losing Heal or Lore - and popping a couple more points into Dex (I don't like it being of a negative value, even if in "full plate and packing sword").

You're quite right about the yardstick Mirnaia, but it's kind of hard not to semi-duplicate it given the lack of bonus feats available (in pre-epic, at least) without deliberately gimping yourself. But I promise I did construct this myself before looking back at the build (which, btw, I had wrong, it was D'Alessandro's build, and is on page 4 of the thread).

And this is where it all goes t*ts up. I can't actually play the damned build atm, so theory is the only place I have left. Clearly, this is the type of build that needs to be practiced with, and it would be pointless to ask someone to test it for me. First, because I've already got Mirnaia running another putative build around for me (brilliantly), and second, I think I'd really need to get a proper feel for this one myself, having never played a Sorcerer in NwN before.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The best of the bunch for spell feats are still, extend, empower & maximize.
That leaves your room for 2XGreater spell focusses pre-epic.
When you reach epic-levels take Epic spell focus, EMA & EW plus Gr. CHAX10.
EMA you want because it lasts all day & adds +5AC even if you are full on magic items (dodge bonus).
With this set-up, you will have maximum DC 45 for your primary school & DC 43 for your secondary, top-notch material.

You could add 1 Paladin & 1 Monk level without loosing practically anything but this is a crutch if you truly want to learn to play a Sorceress.
Learn first how to play her and then adding these little "extras" will feel like you have gained a massive boost in power because you will now know how to take advantage of these.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:I can't actually play the damned build atm, so theory is the only place I have left. Clearly, this is the type of build that needs to be practiced with, and it would be pointless to ask someone to test it for me. First, because I've already got Mirnaia running another putative build around for me (brilliantly), and second, I think I'd really need to get a proper feel for this one myself, having never played a Sorcerer in NwN before.
This build doesn't need "testing". It is a straight up sorcerer, and it will work.
But playing this kind of character is different from what you are used to, so I understand that your need to get a proper feel for it. The only way to do that is to play.

At character creation you will also have to choose between the available familiars, and you choose the spells that you will use at character level 1.
At every level up you can choose to keep the familiar, or choose another one if you want. 

I think we have reached a point where getting used to playing a sorcerer will be the focus. 
I/we can guide you through that as well.
But I will at the same time invite other players to share from their knowledge, habits, tips and tricks that are relevant to where we are in the process.

Deep joy.

Cheers!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
UrbanHermit wrote: ↑
Feb 16, 2020
This has been a very informative (and amusing) thread. Would love to hear of the escapades of Soren one day.
Quoting Mick Dagger:
But how to use spells falls under the lessons for playing a sorcerer.
So, did I miss that part somewhere?

Also, Mick, in that image you posted of your Speed Caster on page one (HIGHLY motivating, btw), I see she's wielding a spear. Would that be for some particular stats on that weapon, or does the evil mistress simply enjoy poking things with a sharp, pointy stick?
Hermit, we never reached the playing part, so you didn't miss anything.
The spear is in fact a little cheat on my part. There is an x-bow  she had with some magical properties. Between act 1 and 2 I exported the character and crafted a spear with the same properties, just for style. I could have done the same with a mage staff or any other simple weapon. It had no impact on game play.
